p: Hepatitis B also has an adverse impact on the quality of life, employment and personal finances of those living with the virus. In 2016, the estimated global impact of hepatitis B on human health and wellbeing was 5,160,000 age-adjusted disability-adjusted life years (DALYs) lost ( 9, 10). The broader societal and economic impact of hepatitis B is often overlooked in fiscal decision-making by governments and funders of health programmes due to the long duration of the disease that precedes the development of end-stage complications ( 11, 12).
